prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Spatial resolution: we propose a 7-field mosaic per source with a final resolution of 0.5" (configuration C34-4 in band6). The sensitivity of 6.2 mJy/beam (see below) is reached in 2min on source with a spectral resolution of 2kms-1. However, we have seven fields per source, and several sources per science goal, therefore the UV coverage will be much better than that of a single observation of only 2minutes. We expect extended emission at least along the major axis of the outflows, so we apply also for ACA and TP time.
Sensitivity: Given the broad H2O profiles in our sources, we base our time estimate on a spectral resolution of 2kms-1. Assuming a typical size for outflows of 20"x5", we derive a lower limit to the expected flux in each ALMA beam by assuming that single dish (APEX) fluxes in CO lines in the EHV wings are uniformly distributed over the 20"x5" area. This leads us to a r.m.s. of 4mJy/beam for a three sigma detection. This sensitivity is reached in the central field of the mosaic (where we expect most of the emission) which is covered by the other six fields (r.m.s. per field=6.2mJy/beam, r.m.s. in the center=/sqrt(3)=3.6mJy/beam).
Spectral setup: With our setup, we cover CO(2-1) and Sio(5-4) (bandwidth 1 and 3, 0.630kms-1 and 0.390kms-1) to resolve outflows and jets. C18O(2-1) (bandiwth 4, 0.771 kms-1) is also covered in order to derive opacities of CO. H2CO(3_03-2_02) is covered to possibly study infall profiles (bandwidth 3, 0.387kms-1). A large spectral window (bandwidth 2, 1.257kms-1) is used to cover the continuum. Additionally other species (SO, HC3N, and H2_13CO) are covered in the previous units.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Molecular outflows are key tracers of star formation and can be used to obtain a clear picture of how massive stars form: they pin-point individual cores, indicate whether an object is pre-stellar or protostellar, and allow measurements of accretion rates. However, there are still many open questions related to massive outflows. Their evolution as function of time is still very unclear because massive young stellar objects are rare and on average distant. With this proposal, we aim to exploit the sensitivity of ALMA to study a sample of massive objects at less than 5.7 kpc to derive a robust picture of the outflow/jet system in each source including its kinematics, morphology and level of multiplicity. The sources are selected from a flux limited sample of 100 ATLASGAL massive clumps and have a H2O 2_02-1-11 line profile broader than 50 kms-1. This sample provides us with a list of sources whose large scale kinematics is dominated by outflows. With the detailed characterization of the cm--IR continuum and unique ancillary line data (APEX, SOFIA, VLT, Herschel) already collected, we will obtain the most comprehensive view of outflows in massive YSOs.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: School of Physics, Exeter, University of
